etymology.description: 可(kě, can/indeed) + 不(bù, not) = rhetorical ‘how could it not’ → emphatic agreement ‘exactly/right’.
etymology.interpretation: Colloquial northern Mandarin affirmation used to strongly echo agreement, functioning like “exactly/right” or “isn’t that so.” Originates from a rhetorical construction where 可 intensifies the negation to imply certainty.

examples.chinese: 你说得对(你說得對)，可不(可不)！
examples.pinyin: Nǐ shuō de duì, kě bù!

examples.chinese: 今天天儿真冷(今天天兒真冷)，可不(可不)！
examples.pinyin: Jīntiān tiānr zhēn lěng, kě bù!

examples.chinese: 这么做更省事(這麼做更省事)，可不(可不)。
examples.pinyin: Zhème zuò gèng shěngshì, kě bù.
examples.english: Doing it this way is even more convenient—exactly.
